div.l: And nyst where she was / for it was derke
But faire and wele / she crepte on to the clerke
And lieth full stille / and wold a caught a slepe
Wᵗithynne a while there this Iohn vp lepe
And on the good wyf / he leith on sore
So mery a fytt had she not full yore
He priketh herd and depe / as he were mad
This Ioly lif han these two clerkes ladde
Tille at the thridde of the belle / þᵉ cokke began̄ to syng
Aleyn wax wery / in the dawnyng
For he had swonken / all the long night
And seid fare wele malkyn̄ / swete wight
The day is come I may no lenger byde
But evir moo whereso I goo or ride
I am thyn owne clerke / so have I sele
Nowe dere lemman̄ qduod she goo fare well
But or þᵘou go oo thyng I wille þᵉ þᵉ telle
Whan̄ thou wendest homward be þᵉ melle
Right at the entre / of the dore behynde
Þᵘou xalt a cake of half a busshell I fynde
That was I maked / of thyn owne mele
Which that I helpe my sire for to stele
And good lemman̄ / god the save and kepe
And wᵗith that woord almost / she gan to wepe
Aleyn̄ vp riste / and thought or þᵗat it dawe
I wille go crepen yn be my felawe
And fonde the cradell wᵗith his hand a noon̄
Be god thought he / alle wrang I have mysgon̄
Myn hede is toty / of my swynke to night
That maketh me / that I go not a right
